1,236.5>>18 May: The German government has provided EUR 440 million (approx. USD 472 million) to Ukraine, with the assistance coordinated by the United Nations.

27 May: The Development Ministry has initiated an emergency programme currently worth EUR 185 million and, in addition, pledged EUR 426 million for the reconstrction of Ukraine during the G7 summit.

10 June: The German government has provided EUR 100 million (approx. USD 107 million) of medical aid since the start of the crisis (the private sector has donated an additional EUR 100 million, but this is not counted as ODA).
Estimated in-donor refugee costs (USD mi: 13,491.4>>19 July: The UNHCR has so far recorded 893000 Ukrainian refugees in Germany. Our estimated average cost of USD 15108 per refugee gives an estimated in-donor refugee cost of USD 13.49 billion.

Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi: 375.4>>14 July: The Canadian government has so far committed CAD 320 million (approx. USD 249 million) in humanitarian funding, CAD 96 million (approx USD 75 million) in development assistance, and CAD 39.7 million (USD 30.9 million) for security, stablization and human rights protection. Additionally, the Canadian government has provided CAD 500 million of a CAD 620 million (approx. USD 483 million) bilateral loan, aimed at enhancing Ukraine’s economic resilience in the midst of Russian aggression (excluded currently as not possible to calculate the grant equivalent element), and CAD 1 billion of the (up to) CAD 1.4 billion loan to the Ukrainian government through a new administered account for Ukraine at the IMF to support Ukraine's economic resiliance. The grant equivalent total is USD 20.5 million.
Estimated in-donor refugee costs (USD mi: 1,796.7>>13 July: The official Canadian Government Website states 151353 temporary resident visa applications have been received since the start of the crisis. Our estimated average cost of USD 11871 per refugee gives an estimated in-donor refugee cost of USD 1.8 billion

Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi: 2,000.0>>5 May: President Emmanuel Macron announced a USD 300 million increase in humanitarian and economics assistance to Ukraine, bringing France's total committed assistance to USD 2 billion since the start of the crisis. However, this USD 2 billion total contains loans which require a calculation as to how much can be counted as ODA. Detail on these loans is lacking, preventing such a calculation at the moment. This total will likely decrease significantly once more detail is released.
Estimated in-donor refugee costs (USD mi: 615.2>>4 July: The UNHCR has so far recorded 92156 Ukrainian refugees in France. Our estimated average cost of USD 6676 per refugee gives an estimated in-donor refugee cost of USD 0.62 billion.

Estimated in-donor refugee costs (USD mi: 613.6>>19 July: The UNHCR has so far recorded 31826 Ukrainian refugees in Denmark. Our estimated average cost of USD 19280 per refugee gives an estimated in-donor refugee cost of USD 0.61 billion.

Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi:
559.1>>27 May: Up until May 27, the Japanese government has implemented emergency humanitarian assistance in Ukraine and neighbouring countries up to USD 200 million, expressed an interest in a USD 600 million loan (see 7 June source), and committed JPY 300 million (approx. USD 2.2 million) of grant aid for the "Economic and Social Development Programme". On the 27th May, they increased funding to Ukraine's Emergency Grant Aid a further USD 1.66 million.

7 June: The Japanese government have since signed additional loan funding for the "Emergency Economic Reconstruction Development Policy Loan" of JPY 65 billion on top of the original JPY 13 billion, bringing the total to JPY 73 billion (approx. Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi:
2,148.0>>5 May: President Ursula von der Leyen announced new aid package of €200 million to support displaced people in Ukraine

30 May: As part of the April 9th 'Stand Up for Ukraine' pledging event, the EC pledged a total of EUR 1 billion, consisting of EUR 600 million million for internally displaced people in Ukraine, via the repurposing of existing funds and humanitarian assistance, and EUR 400 million for Ukrainian refugees in frontline Member States via repurposed and new home affairs funds. The EU also allocated a further EUR 45 million in humanitarian funding for projects in Ukraine. We exclude EBRD's EUR 1 billion loan to cover the needs of people displaced bt the invasion pledged at this event.

30 May: Approximatley EUR 14 million has been sent to Ukraine via the rescEU medical stockpiles based in Germany, HUngary and the Netherlands.

21 July: Ukraine recieved EUR 120 million in the form of grants as part of a State and Resilience Building Contract (SRBC), to support societal and state resilience in Ukraine. This grant came with a EUR 1.2 billion loan of Macro Financial Assistance, which we have excluded due to insufficient detail to calculate a grant equivalent measure.

21 July: EUR 330 million has been provided to an emergency support programme that helps to secure access to basic goods and services, such as to education, healthcare and food in Ukraine.

21 July: Currently, EUR 335 million has been made available for humanitarian aid projects to help civilians affected by the war in Ukraine (excluding EUR 13 million for Moldova).

Estimated ODA pledged to Ukraine (USD mi:
95.0>>24 March: South Korea initially sent USD 0.8 million of non-lethal aid to Ukraine, including bulletproof helmets, tents, blankets and first-aid kits

6 May: Since the start of the crisis, the Korean government has announced a total of USD 40 million of assistance to Ukraine, including USD 10 million in the first round of assistance on Feb 28, and USD 30 million for additional assistance on April 7.

4 June: The United Nations' World Food Program announced South Korea's USD 3 million contribution to their emergency relief efforts in Ukraine.

9 June: With Ukraine's nuclear power plants under threat of military conflict, the Korean government has provided assistance of USD 1.2 million to Ukraine through the International Atomic Energy Agency.

21 June: The Korean government has decided to provide an additional US$50 million in humanitarian assistance.
